info.author: Luke Murphy
info.description:
# ytmetrics

# Install It

It's easy with [pip]:

[pip]: https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/installing/

```bash
$ pip install ytwizard
```

# Use It

Just run the following to see available commands:

```bash
$ ytwizard --help
```

Any sub-command has a help function too:

```bash
$ ytwizard credentials --help
```

## Get Authenticated

Firstly, some context: in order to use the tool, you need to have
authentication credentials. These are normally contained in a
`credentials.json`. If you do not have this file, you'll typically have been
given a `client_secrets.json` file by your Youtube account administrator.

If you have a `credentials.json`, either place it in the directory you are
running your `ytwizard` commands in. Or, export an environment variable with
the path to the file with:

```bash
$ export CREDENTIALS_FILE=credentials.json
```

If you do not have this file, then place your `client_secrets.json` in the current
directory where you are running your `ytwizard` commands. Or, export an environment
variable with the path to the file with:

```bash
$ export CLIENT_SECRETS_FILE=client_secrets.json
```

Then, to obtain credentials, simply run:

```bash
$ ytwizard credentials
```
# Hack It

Install [pipenv] and simply run:

[pipenv]: https://docs.pipenv.org/en/latest/advanced.html#fancy-installation-of-pipenv

```bash
$ pipenv install --dev
```

Then drop into a pipenv aware shell environment with:

```bash
$ pipenv shell
```
